question: Move back. Where's the stairs? 5A. How long ago did he stop breathing? We'll do all we can. Clear! Clear!
answer: No more, please don't!

question: In the last year I had come to believe in such things as spirits leaving the body and not wanting to be put back, spirits angry at the awkward places death had left them. I understood how crazy it was to think this way, but I was convinced if I turned around, I'd see Old Man Burke standing at the window, watching, waiting for us to finish. I'll take over. Call ER and ask for an eighty-three. Sorry. Do you have any music?
answer: What?

question: Music. I think it helps if you play something he liked.
answer: John, play the Sinatra. Play the Sinatra.

question: Don't take another step. We're on diversion. Can't accept any more patients. Your dispatcher should have told you.
answer: We got him at Eighteen and Second. You're closest.

question: Where will I put him, Frank? Look. Tell me.
answer: He wanted to come here. Said the nurses at Misery were the best.

question: The Chinese close in five minutes. Beef lo mein. It's been on my mind since I woke. Whatjathink?
answer: I think the moment that food hits your mouth we'll get a job.

question: Turn here. You missed it. The Chink is on 3rd. Some partner you are Frank. I coulda walked there faster. I'm starving and you stop to talk to hookers. You're making me nuts. Is that what you're trying to do, drag me down with you to nutsville? Oh no!--I just remembered.
answer: What?

question: I'm so stupid. I had beef lo mein last night. I can't eat the same thing two nights in a row. It's almost two o'clock, what the hell am I gonna do? What you getting?
answer: I'm not hungry.

question: Oh yeah, you don't eat food.
answer: I eat. I just haven't had coffee yet.

question: Coffee and whiskey, lucky you ain't dead with that diet. Wait, I've got it. Half fried chicken with fries. Let's go, hurry up. Come on.
answer: Rose was getting closer. Ever since the call a month before, when I'd lost her, she seemed like all the girls in the neighborhood. One of the first things you learn is to avoid bad memories. I used to be an expert, but lately I'd found some holes. Anything could trigger it. The last month belonged to Rose, but there were a hundred more ready to come out. These spirits were part of the job. It was impossible to pass a building that didn't bold the spirit of something I could handle that. What haunted me now was more savage

question: Turn it off.
answer: What?

question: You know what. The radio. Let's do it. It might be a good one.
answer: You wanted it turned off. There's no such thing as a good fire. People get burned up. They can't breathe.

question: That's what we're here for. Come on, Frank.
answer: Don't push it, Larry.

question: You're burned out.
answer: One-three Zebra. Zebra three, I need you.

question: You see, he's giving it to us anyway.
answer: Zebra, are you there? I'm holding an unconscious at First and St. Marks.

question: It's Mr. Oh. I'm not answering it.
answer: Answer the radio Zebra. You know it's that time.

question: Four times this week I've had him. Aren't there any other units out there? Don't answer the radio. They'll give it to someone else.
answer: Thirteen Zebra. One-Three Zebra. You're going out of service in two seconds.

question: Look, Frank, when I say don't answer it, that means answer it. You can do that for me at least. Three Zebra.
answer: Yes, Zebra. You'll be driving to the man who needs no introduction, chronic caller of the year three straight and shooting for number four. The duke of drunk, the king of stink, our most frequent flier, Mr. Oh.

question: Ten-four. Don't go. Not this time.
answer: Relax, it's a street job, easy except for the smell. We'll just throw him in back and zip over to Mercy--no blood, no dying, that's how I look at it. He's just a drunk.

question: It's not our job to taxi drunks around.
answer: They'll just keep calling.

question: Someone's gonna die someday causa that bum, going to have a cardiac and the only medics will be taking care of Mr. Oh. So what's different?
answer: Well why didn't you say so?

question: He's drunk. He's fine. He can walk to the hospital. Don't start that. I've seen him walk. He walks better than me. That's him, Mr. Oh. Get up. Faster! God!
answer: Faster!

question: It's my first cigarette in over a year.
answer: The first is always the best.

question: It's the waiting that's killing me, not knowing, you know? It's really hard on my mother. The doctor doesn't think my father'll make it. He says he was dead too long, after six minutes the brain starts to die and once that goes, close the door.
answer: You never know.

question: I mean if he was dead, I could handle that.
answer: At least he's got people around him.

question: I'm not so sure. My father and I haven't spoken in three years. When my brother called to say my father was having a heart attack, that he'd locked himself in the bathroom, all the way going over I was thinking how I was gonna tell him what a bastard he was. Then when I got up the stairs and we moved him onto the bed, I thought of all these other things I wanted to say.
answer: Even when you say the things, there's always more things.

question: Right now, I'm more worried about my mother than anything. They won't let her see my father.
answer: Go home. Take her home. Get some rest. Not going to find anything out now.

question: Larry, swing over on Eighth. We're gonna hafta run one of these calls.
answer: Relax, will you.

question: The biggest problem with not driving is that whenever there's a patient in back you're also in the back. The doors close, you're trapped. Four in the morning is always the worst time for me, just before dawn, just when you've been lulled into thinking it might be safe to close your eyes for one minute. That's when I first found Rose ... She was on the sidewalk, not breathing. I'm not feeling very well, Larry. I say we go back to the hospital and call it a night.
answer: You have no sick time, Frank. No time of any kind. Everyone knows that.

question: Take me back, put me to bed; I surrender. We've done enough damage tonight.
answer: You take things too seriously. Look at us, we're cruising around, talking, taking some quiet time, getting paid for it. We've got a good job here.

question: Yeah, you're right. Tell me, you ever think of doing anything else?
answer: Sure, I'm taking the captain's exam next year. After the kids are in school, Louise can go back to the post office and, I thought, what the hell, I'll start my own medic service. Out on the Island the volunteers are becoming salaried municipal. It's just a matter of time and who you know. Someday it's going to be Chief Larry calling the shots.

question: I'd always had nightmares, but now the ghosts didn't wait for me to sleep. I drank every day. Help others and you help yourself, that was my motto, but I hadn't saved anyone in months. It seemed all my patients were dying. I'd waited, sure the sickness would break, tomorrow night, the next call, the feeling would drop away. More than anything else I wanted to sleep like that, close my eyes and drift away ...
answer: Zebra. One-three Zebra. Zebra, answer the radio. Come on, I've got one for you. Pick up the radio and push the button on the side and speak into the front.

question: Zebra.
answer: Male bleeding, corner of Houston and One. No further information.

question: At the hospital. You told me at the hospital.
answer: Where you hit? Major Tom, I'm going to Misery. You take yours to Bellvue. You're gonna feel a stick in your arm. Don't move.

question: I want to die. I'm the one.
answer: You're not going to die.

question: What did you say?
answer: Shut up. You're going to die and he's not. Got it. I can't. I got to do the other arm. Hold this--right there. If you let go, I swear, I won't kill you.

question: That boy you brought in, he was shot, wasn't he?
answer: Yes.

question: He's dead, huh?
answer: Yes.

question: I think this place stinks.
answer: Our Lady of Misery.

question: Did you see my father?
answer: No.

question: It's crazy in there. What's wrong with that doctor? He keeps mumbling, poking himself in the eye when he talks to me.
answer: He's working a double shift.

question: Thing is, I'm supposed to be the fuckup. The one on the stretcher in there--that's supposed to be me. With my parents crying out here. I got a lot of guilt, you know what I mean? My father's in a coma, now my mother's going crazy. It's like she's in a trance.
answer: She should go home.

question: I'd take her, but then who would stay here?
answer: Here she is.

question: You saw him?
answer: Mrs. Burke, please, they'll take care of him. You should go home now. Larry and I'll drop her back home. Help me get her to the ambulance.

question: Thank you.
answer: Saving someone's life is like falling in love, the best drug in the world. For days, sometimes weeks afterwards, you walk the street making infinite whatever you see. Once, for weeks I couldn't feel the earth. Everything I touched became light. Horns played in my shoes; flowers fell from my pockets ... You wonder if you've become immortal, as if you saved your own life as well. What was once criminal and happenstance suddenly makes sense. God has passed through you, why deny it, that for a moment there, God was you. Good morning, Captain.

question: Saving someone's life is like falling in love, the best drug in the world. For days, sometimes weeks afterwards, you walk the street making infinite whatever you see. Once, for weeks I couldn't feel the earth. Everything I touched became light. Horns played in my shoes; flowers fell from my pockets ... You wonder if you've become immortal, as if you saved your own life as well. What was once criminal and happenstance suddenly makes sense. God has passed through you, why deny it, that for a moment there, God was you. Good morning, Captain.
answer: What am I going to to do with this guy? Pierce, I was just on the phone with Borough Command. Out of twelve shifts this month, you've been late for nine, sick four and that includes the shift where you came late and went home early.

question: I'm sick. That's what I've been telling you.
answer: You're killing me, you know that? You got no sick time according to Command. I've been told to terminate.

question: It's okay. I'll just get my things out of the locker.
answer: I've never fired anyone in my life.

question: I'm sorry Captain. Don't take it too hard.
answer: Nobody tells me to fire anyone. I told them

question: You know they won't do it. It's up to you. You gotta be strong.
answer: I feel for you, but we got an emergency here. It's a weekend of full moons. Everyone's called in sick. Larry, Veeber, Stanley too. We need bodies out there. I had to put Marcus on Twelve Young. You know he's not supposed to work two nights in a row.

question: You swore you'd fire me if I came in late again.
answer: I'll fire you tomorrow. Hell, better than that, I'll forward you some sick time. A week, two weeks off-- how about that?

question: I don't think a week's gonna do it.
answer: I'm sorry, Pierce. You're going out with Marcus. Duty calls. The City needs you.

question: My Lord mother man, you look like hell. What were you drinking?
answer: The captain almost fired me tonight. I'm on my way out. Anytime now.

question: Nobody gets fired. Look at me. Only thing they might do is transfer you to the Bronx. You look like you aged ten years since I rode with you last.
answer: The ghosts--

question: You ever notice people who see shit always, are crazy?
answer: I think the worst is over.

question: She loves me the way no woman ever has.
answer: Twelve Young, I don't have time for your games. Now answer me or do I have to come out there myself?

question: I usually don't do calls before coffee. But I think it might do you some good. Twelve Young is here and I'm gonna take care of you, baby. Don't you worry about a thing, yahear, cause Marcus is alive and on arrival.
answer: I'm not your baby, Young, I'm not your mother either. You're going to a cardiac arrest, Avenue C and Ninth, northeast corner. It's a club. Take the side entrance.

question: Ten-four, hon. This is for you. I hope we're not late from you guys holding us up here. Okay, what happened?
answer: He's going to be all right, right?

question: No. He's dead.
answer: No way, man.

question: I'm still waiting and this young man is still dead.
answer: All right, all right, he's been snorting that Red Death stuff. Been going for four days.

question: What's his name?
answer: IB Bangin.

question: What'd you mean IB Bangin? What kind of name is IB Bangin?
answer: It's Frederick. Frederick Smith.

question: Okay, Freddy.
answer: It's Frederick.

question: Okay, IB Bangin, we're gonna bring you back. Every person here grab the hand of the person next to you. Oh Lord, here I am again to ask one more chance for a sinner. Bring back IB Bangin, Lord. You have the power, the might, the super light, to spare this worthless man.
answer: Frederick! You died, you stupid bastard. I warned you.

question: That guy I brought in yesterday, post-cardiac arrest. He's gone.
answer: Burke. You won't believe it. He's showing cognitive signs. He started with spontaneous respiration, now he's fighting to pull out the tube. Had to sedate him. He's in a CAT scan. I'm giving him every test I can

question: What do you think?
answer: Who knows? It's all lower-brain-stem- activity. The heart refuses to stabilize--he's coded eleven times since he got here. This guy's a fighter. Every time the Valium wears off he starts yanking those restraints.

question: The family know?
answer: I wanted to bring them in, to see if he'd respond to voices, but they weren't in the waiting room. The guy's daughter was in my face all last night and when I finally have something positive to tell her, she's gone.

question: Make a left here. I want to stop. I'll be right back.
answer: Yes?

question: Hello, I'm Frank Pierce, from the ambulance last night. I brought your father into the hospital and I just learned some news.
answer: I'll be right down. He's better, isn't he?

question: Well, the doctor says he's showing some movement. It's still early, it might mean nothing, but I thought you'd want to know.
answer: I knew. I sensed it when I heard your voice.

question: You look so different.
answer: I know. It's awful, isn't it? Night of the Living Cheerleaders.

question: I think it looks good.
answer: I was going nuts in that waiting room so I came back to check on my mom.

question: How is she?
answer: Sleeping.

question: I was just going to get some food. Pizza. Maybe we could.
answer: You can't kill my father that easy. He'll fight forever. Like with me

question: Be tough to get a taxi here. We can give you a ride if you like.
answer: Okay.

question: Who's that?
answer: She's the daughter of a cardiac arrest I brought in last night. I told her we'd give her a ride back to Misery. Her father's showing signs of improving.

question: Oh, Frank, you've got it bad, so much worse than I thought.
answer: I'm hungry too. We gotta get some food after this.

question: Why don't we go outside for a little while, wait until this passes. He wants to pull that tube out. It's pretty painful--that's why they keep him sedated--but it's a good sign.
answer: You sure? I know my father would hate to be tied down. He wouldn't even go to the dentist.

question: That's how it's done. You have to keep the body going until the brain and heart recover enough to go on their own.
answer: He's better, though, right?

question: He's better.
answer: Look, I'm sorry, but it's important to me. I mean, a week ago I was wishing he was dead. And now I want hear his voice again, just once more-- you know what I mean?

question: Thanks.
answer: I'm not really hungry. My father was a great man, you know. There was nobody he wouldn't help. You know that crazy guy Noel who I gave water to last night? He lived in our house for almost a year. A total stranger he'd do anything for, his own family though ...

question: It's best not to ... It's good pizza, huh?
answer: Not as good as Nino's.

question: You remember that pizza place, Joe's on Tenth Street maybe fifteen years ago? When you ordered a pie it came with a little plastic madonna in the middle?
answer: Yeah, or Saint Anthony. You from the neighborhood?

question: I grew up on Elizabeth. I went to Blessed Sacrament.
answer: On yeah? I went to Holy Name. Where'd you go to high school?

question: We moved out after that. Upstate.
answer: Like everybody else--except us. Always standing on the sidewalk waving goodbye to moving trucks. Your parents ... ?

question: They're fine. My old man was a bus driver, mom a nurse--I was sort of born to it, I guess.
answer: You married?

question: Ah, no. I was. It's hard to explain. She had a hard time adjusting to, well, maybe it was my fault too.
answer: Is it always this bad in here? I mean, how does anyone survive?

question: It's been bad lately, but it's always bad.
answer: How long you been doing this?

question: Five years.
answer: Wow, you musta seen some things, huh? What's the worst thing you ever seen?

question: You learn to sort of block it out, you know, like cops fence off a crime scene. But then something good will happen and everything will just glow.
answer: You must get a lot of overdoses. I bet you picked me up a couple of times.

question: I think I'd remember that.
answer: Maybe not. I was a different person then. Does everybody you meet spill their problems on you like this?

question: Mostly. It must be my face. My mother always said I looked like a priest.
answer: I better go check on my father. Thanks for the pizza. I owe you one. Maybe when he gets better, you know, when we're done with all this.

question: Sure. Look after her, Griss, okay?
answer: Rule number one

question: What about rule number three
answer: You don't know the first thing about rule number three, cannot begin to understand the complexities of that rule. Come on, let's go look at some hookers. The Kit Kat will be letting out. Don't ever call a junkie whore a crackhead. They get real mad. Look at these women. You can't even tell who's a hooker anymore. Whatever happened to go-go boots and hot pants? They wear anything now, walk outta the house with whatever they got on ...

question: The street is so much more unpredictable than the ER and to prepare for the unexpected I was taught to act without thinking, like an army private who can take apart and reassemble a gun blindfolded ... I realized that my training was useful in less than ten percent of the calls and saving someone's life was rarer than that. As the years went by I grew to understand that my role was less about saving lives than about bearing witness. I was a grief mop and much of my job was to remove, if even for a short time, the grief starter or the grief product. It was enough I simply showed up.
answer: ... look at her. Leaves you no idea what's underneath, not even a suggestion. Could be a skeleton for all you know. Nice though, pulling back her hood as we drive by. There's a mystery to it, then she shows you.

question: She's no whore, Marcus.
answer: We're all whores, Frank. You know what I'm talking about, the way she looked at me.

question: She wasn't looking at you, man, she was looking at me. I didn't kill you.
answer: No, you didn't, Frank, thank you. But there's still a couple hours left on the shift.

question: Twelve Young, answer the radio. I have a call for you.
answer: She said to me, I love the way you talk on the radio.

question: I can't wait all night, Young. I'm holding a priority and if you don't answer I'm going to knock you out of service.
answer: Don't worry, hon. Young is here and he's gonna help out--just remember, you owe me.

question: You're going to three-four Avenue C, 17 year-old female cardiac arrest, no further information.
answer: Ten-four, hon. Look at that. A fat junkie. That's a first.

question: What's wrong.
answer: No English. She has terrible pain in her belly.

question: Pregnant.
answer: No, no, that's impossible.

question: Are you pregnant? Estas embarazada? Can you walk? Puedes caminar?
answer: She say she in great pain.

question: You know each other a long time?
answer: Two years. Ever since we left island.

question: In that time, you ever have sex?
answer: Never. No cigarettes, no drugs, no booze.

question: No underwear?
answer: We are virgins.

question: Oh Jesus, we'd better go. Call for backup. It's coming. Hold her down.
answer: What's that, Frank?

question: Three legs.
answer: That's too many.

question: Backup?
answer: It's coming.

question: Is she dying?
answer: She's having a baby. Twins.

question: Es impossible.
answer: You can trust me on this one.

question: It's a miracle.
answer: You take the first one.

question: Don't give me that look.
answer: What look?

question: You know what I'm talking about. It's all over your face. That I-just- saved-a-little-baby-boy look.
answer: We just saved a little baby boy. Think of it that way.

question: I don't want to hear about it, okay? That's three jobs for the night. It's over. Three jobs and time for a drink. Six am, the cocktail hour. Pass the bottle; I know you're holding.
answer: The bar is now open.

question: I hate vodka.
answer: Please, a little decorum if you will. What I was going to say is, is that holding that baby in my arms, I felt like I was twenty-one again. A call like that makes me think of going back to three nights a week, not two, start running again, cut down on the drinking.

question: I'll drink to that.
answer: Here's to the greatest job in the world.

question: Excuse me. You seemed like you were in trouble.
answer: I'm all right. I just can't stand to see people tied up. I'm in the waiting room for hours, listening to Noel screaming. The only reason he's screaming is 'cause he's tied up.

question: Don't seem so bad to me.
answer: Don't say that. I wanted to cut my father loose too. They told me he almost died and five minutes later they say he's better and I go in. It's killing me seeing him fighting like that. Look, since you're here, maybe you could do me a favor. I need you to wait for me outside this building, okay? I have to visit a friend who's sick.

question: Okay.
answer: I'm only asking because it's a dangerous building. There's been some robberies, a woman was raped not long ago. This woman I'm seeing, she'll want to talk to me all day, but if I can point to you out the window and say you're waiting, I can be out quick. if anything happens, I'll be in apartment 16M.

question: Maybe I should come up with you.
answer: If I'm not back in fifteen minutes, hit the buzzer. That way she'll let me go.

question: Nothing's going to happen. I'll come with you.
answer: No, I'll be fine. I'm just visiting a sick friend. I shouldn't have asked you to come.

question: You asked me not to come.
answer: Promise you won't go inside.

question: Fifteen minutes.
answer: I just have to relax a little. Not feel so guilty all the time.

question: We can still go back. I'll walk you home. You sleep a couple of hours, watch some TV, take a bath.
answer: Don't be a cop. If you have any doubts about this, it's my fault. You go on home, okay. I'm fine, really. I don't need you. Thanks.

question: He's not a cop, he's a medic. I'm CY Coates.
answer: Frank Pierce.

question: Mary said you might be coming.
answer: Where is she?

question: Sleeping in the back.
answer: She asked me to pick her up.

question: I know, but she told me to tell you she wants to crash here a few hours. Terrible about her father, isn't it?
answer: I better just go in and see her.

question: I call this the Oasis. Refuge from the world out there. Did you know two people were shot in this building last week? Careful. That's the Tiger. The lady's down the hall. Welcome to Sunrise Enterprises, Frank, the stress-free factory.
answer: Mary. Mary, we've got to get going.

question: She wanted something to help her sleep.
answer: Mary, we really have to go.

question: Frank, she's suffered enough. She's okay, I promise. C'mon, Frank. I'm always interested in people in stressful occupations and being a paramedic is about as stressful as I can imagine. Here, sit down. What's it like? Tell me some war stories.
answer: Got a beer?

question: That shit is poison, Frank. We don't drink alcohol here. What you need is one of these.
answer: Did you give Mary something called Red Death?

question: Red Death? Tell me something, Frank--does killing your clients make good business sense to you? The kids selling that shit have no sense. They'll be taken care of, don't worry about that.
answer: I should be going. I just quit.

question: Sleep is all stress reduction. Here. You take one of these, sleep two hours, that's all you need. Why do you think I'm telling you this, Frank--for my health? You ought to look at yourself in the mirror, man. Kanita, get him a glass of water.
answer: Is this what you gave Mary?

question: That's the stuff. I call it the Red Lion. Very king-of-the-jungle. Frank, I'm trying to help you. Drink up.
answer: I guess I'll be going.

question: You're in the stomach!
answer: You sure? Huh?

question: You're in the stomach, man. You're in the stomach! Let me try.
answer: One more time!

question: Stomach again.
answer: No way!

question: Frank, take it easy. what happened?
answer: He flipped out.

question: Be cool, man. You're having a paradoxical reaction. It can happen. Didn't I tell you this guy was stressed out?
answer: Stressed? He's psycho.

question: I can walk. Let go of me. You shouldn't have come up. I told you not to. You could have gotten us both killed. You and CY have a nice talk? He tell you about Sunrise Enterprises, helping people? Well, I've seen him hurt people. Why are you following me?
answer: Because you can barely walk.

question: You remember Noel, from the other night, how Noel is now? He wasn't always like that. He was my brother's best friend. Cy or Tiger or one of those other goons put a bullet in Noel's head. He was in a coma three months. Crazy ever since. This is my place. What is it? You want to help me, you feel sorry for me? Keep it to yourself.
answer: I need to sit down a minute.

question: Or maybe you wanna fuck me? Everyone else has. I've been clean two years now. I got a job. I paint when I'm home. Don't bother anybody. Then all this shit happens. Oh no you don't. You can't stay here.
answer: Hello, I'm Frank. Mary's friend. A very close friend who loves animals. Hello? I washed my face with three kinds of soap, each smelling like a different season. It felt good to be in a woman's room again, especially a woman who wasn't comatose or severely disabled. I felt that perhaps I had turned a corner, like I saved someone, though I didn't know who.

question: Hello, I'm Frank. Mary's friend. A very close friend who loves animals. Hello? I washed my face with three kinds of soap, each smelling like a different season. It felt good to be in a woman's room again, especially a woman who wasn't comatose or severely disabled. I felt that perhaps I had turned a corner, like I saved someone, though I didn't know who.
answer: You're late, Pierce. I know, but I can't fire you. I've got nobody to work sixteen XRay with Walls.

question: No ...
answer: I got some forms here to fill out about that accident when you get the time. I'll fire you tomorrow. I promise.

question: What if there is no tomorrow?
answer: Go on, get outta here, Pierce, before I give you a big hug. I love this guy.

question: Go to the bank, boy, take out everything you can.
answer: Mr. Burke?

question: I'm going. I've had enough.
answer: You do it.

question: Don't do it.
answer: I thought he was getting better. Why not? Clear!

question: Frank, what you doing back there?
answer: I'm sick, Tom. I need a cure. Vitamin B cocktail, followed by an amp of glucose and a drop of adrenaline. Not as good as beer, but all I got.

question: Come on, Frank. There's blood spilling in the streets.
answer: These are hard times, Tom.

question: Yeah. Great, isn't it?
answer: Great to be drunk. Sobriety's killing me.

question: Look up, Frank. Full moon. The blood's gonna run tonight. I can feel it. Our mission
answer: Our mission is coffee, Tom. A shot of the bull, Puerto Rican espresso.

question: Ten-four. El Toro de Oro. Blast off.
answer: The cure's not working, Tom. Maybe we should go back to the hospital.

question: Tom, where are the Band-aids? This is an ambulance, isn't it?
answer: Look out! What the hell's going on? Hold it. I will not take anyone anywhere against his will. This is America. People have rights. You're lucky you didn't kill him. We're going to hear it straight from the loony's mouth. Are you crazy? Did you try to bump yourself off? Why didn't you say so. Sir, I am going to give you some medicine that is still very experimental. It's from NASA, and although the astronauts have been using it for years, we are the first service to try it. I will put this patch on your forehead like this, and in about a minute you will have to relax. You will forget all your suicidal feelings. It's very important that you wear this for a least twenty- four hours and keep checking the mirror. If the patch turns green you have to see the doctor immediately. The side effects could be fatal.

question: This is the worst suicide attempt I've ever seen. You feel the pulse? Here. That's where you cut, and it's not across, it's down like so. Here take it. With all the poor people of this city who wanted only to live and were viciously murdered, you have the nerve to sit here waiting to die and not go through with it. You make me sick. Take it.
answer: We cured him, Frank. When we work together there's nothing we can't fix. Sounds like they're trying to clean up the bus terminal tonight, Hello, hello. Major Tom to Frank, time to come home. Where you going?

question: C'mon, Tom. The city's burning.
answer: Whatja doing?

question: I feel the need, the need for speed. I'm driving out of myself.
answer: The brakes are shot.

question: I've taken that into consideration.
answer: You okay?

question: I'm going to thirteen.
answer: Get this, Frank--we got two patients. Number one, the scarecrow outside. Number two misses the railing but breaks both legs on the balcony, then throws himself through a glass window, heads to the bedroom, where he's now passed out.

question: Well, he's the steakhead of the night, then.
answer: I don't think the fire people can touch him out there.

question: How's he doing?
answer: I haven't had a chance to see him yet. I'm going to take care of sleeping beauty.

question: Does that hurt?
answer: No!

question: I don't think you've hurt any major organs. We got to get you off this thing without setting off bleeding. They're gonna torch the fence. You're gonna feel the metal getting warm, maybe very warm.
answer: I can't hold up my head anymore. So, Frank, am I going to live?

question: You're going to live.
answer: I've been thinking about things. Meditating on my financial future. You guys gave me plenty of time to meditate on the future. Whatja do, stop for Chinese on the way over? There's plenty of food in my place.

question: I was tired. I needed a coffee.
answer: What about Kanita?

question: Dead.
answer: That's too bad. Get some money, a nice looking girl on your arm, and everyone wants to take a piece. Some kid I wouldn't let wash my Mercedes is in my house, shooting at me. Damn, I thought I could make it onto the balcony like Tiger. He's fat, that's why, falls faster. I'm trying to watch my weight, and look what happens. Am I shot, Frank?

question: No.
answer: Boy can't shoot for shit, either. Goddamn that's hot. Isn't it beautiful? When the fires start to fall, then the strongest rule it all. I love this city.

question: Give me a hand, Frank. I've got to get something between those teeth. You can't believe how much he's improved.
answer: How many times have you shocked him tonight?

question: Fourteen. We finally got him a room upstairs. Should be up there in a couple of hours.
answer: What do you do, just have someone follow him around with a defribilator?

question: That's good, Frank. No, but they might surgically implant one, about the size of my thumb. It goes near the shoulder here, with two electrodes connected to the heart. It sends a shock whenever it senses a drop in blood flow. Amazing, isn't it?
answer: A medical miracle.

question: I heard CY Coates was brought in. He looked pretty bad.
answer: He'll be all right.

question: Too bad. He called me up today, can you believe that? I don't know how he got my number. He asks me do I want to come over and see him, I tell him I'd rather go to a leper colony. He says there's a new gang that wants to kill him, take over the business. I told him I hope he's right. That they kill him. That's what I told him.
answer: It'll be a while before he's up and running again.

question: OK, last night I was weak. it won't happen again. And all that shit I said--it was just because I was stoned. Forget it.
answer: No problem. Thanks for letting me crash. It was the best sleep I've had in months. I used some of your soap.

question: I wish these people would leave already. I can't listen to another story. Did you see him? That doctor says the brain is coming around. They're waiting for the heart to stabilize. I don't know who to believe. He says they still have to keep him tied up.
answer: Can I bring you something back to eat--a falafal, some pizza?

question: No, we just ate. I only remember how tough my father was. Now I know he had to be like that, to make us tough. This city'll kill you if you aren't strong enough.
answer: No, the city doesn't discriminate. It gets everybody. I gotta go. Another call. We're all dying, Mary Burke.

question: This is not a good time.
answer: There's no time.

question: C'mon, Tom, pick up a job.
answer: You want some bum in the bus terminal? We'll wait for a real call.

question: Let's get in a fight, then.
answer: Who with?

question: That's your job. Just keep driving, keep moving. No stopping. We're sharks. We stop too long, we die. Let's break something, Tom. Let's bust something, bomb something.
answer: What do you want to break?

question: I don't know--let's break some windows.
answer: Why?

question: Destruction, distraction. I feel the need.
answer: You need a reason, Frank. You don't just go around breaking people's windows. That's anarchy.

question: What's the reason? Give me a reason, Tom.
answer: Let me think. Classic cabbie move. Hey, swammy, that's called a crosswalk. You stop before it, not on it! I know who to work over. Him. This guy's been terrorizing the neighborhood for weeks, ever since he got outta jail, wreaking general havoc, contributing to the bad name of the place. The term "menace to society" was made up for him.

question: He's crazy. He can't help it.
answer: Well, why don't they put him away? Prisons don't want him. I took him to the hospital yesterday and here he is again. Look at that. Tell me that's a crazy person. Every move is calculated. He knows exactly what he's doing. This is the guy. I've been after him for weeks. He's quick, runs like a rat, tough for one person, but with two of us--

question: Okay, whatta I do?
answer: If he sees me, he'll run, so I'll get out here. You start talking to him about baseball or something while I sneak around behind and get down and you push him. When he falls we get him.

question: That's ridiculous.
answer: Believe me, it always works. The simpler, the better.

question: You learn that in the army? Flatbush. That's a hell of a swing you got there, Noel. I'm thinking Strawberry in his prime.
answer: Strawberry ain't shit. Drug pussy. Me. I swing like Reggie. Mr. October. Number three, game six, World Series. Here, you try.

question: No, I'd better not.
answer: Sure, sure, give go.

question: Yeah? What the hell. The next year, tiebreaker for the division, in Boston, Yanks down two to nothing, Bucky Dent steps to the plate.
answer: Oh man, Bucky.

question: The pitch, high heater. Bucky knows what's coming. He steps in, smash, over the green monster.
answer: Frank, what the hell are you doing? You go down those stairs there. Meet me back here if you can't find him in ten minutes. Call out if you see him. Get with the program, Frank.

question: I didn't mean to. I tried to help. I wanted to.
answer: I got him, Frank! To the moon, Alice! You little motherfucker!

question: Get the kit! We're gonna tube him!
answer: Frank!

question: Do it!
answer: Frank!

question: We're gonna save you, Noel. You're gonna be all right. Do it, Tom! I'll call for fucking backup, I swear!
answer: You're crazy.

question: Last show of the night.
answer: Jesus Christ. Nurse Crupp! Anybody else hurt?

question: No.
answer: Crazy fucker.

question: Where's Burke?
answer: Upstairs. 212. Had to shock him twice more. Christ, what a way to start the day. He's in V-fib. Shock him. Zap him again. Nothing. Get the cart, start compressions, get an epinephrine in. That's enough. I called it. Let's get some coffee. You gonna tell the family?
